<Summary source="https://www.abs.gov.au/statistics/labour/employment-and-unemployment/labour-force-australia/latest-release">
# Summary of ABS Labour Force Statistics - December 2025

## Key Statistics (December 2025)

**Note:** The article provides trend estimates for December 2025 but does not explicitly state the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for December 2025 in the extracted content. The article mentions both trend and seasonally adjusted terms are reported but the specific unemployment rate figure is not included in the provided text.

### Employment (Trend terms):
- Employment increased by 24,800 people (0.2%) to 14,686,100 people
- Employment-to-population ratio remained at 64.0%
- Monthly hours worked increased to 1,997 million hours

### Other Key Information:
- The participation rate data is mentioned but specific figures are not provided in the extracted content
- The article references both trend and seasonally adjusted estimates but the specific unemployment rate figures are not included in the provided excerpt

## Important Caveats:
- **Data Quality Warning:** The ABS advises using caution when analyzing movements between November and December 2025 data, following operational challenges in the collection of November's data
- The ABS is modernizing the Labour Force Survey to improve collection methods

## Methodology Notes:
- Labour Force Survey results are released in three stages
- The survey covers Australia's resident civilian population aged 15 years and over
- Data is available monthly from various historical starting points depending on the specific metric

**Disclaimer:** The extracted content does not include the specific unemployment rate figure for December 2025, which would be the most directly relevant statistic for forecasting February 2026 unemployment.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.roymorgan.com/findings/10122-australian-unemployment-estimates-december-2025-002">
# Summary of Roy Morgan Research Article on Australian Unemployment (December 2025)

## Key Statistics (December 2025):

**Unemployment:**
- 'Real' unemployment: 1,669,000 (10.4% of workforce, up 0.2% from November)
- Increased by 41,000 from November
- Looking for full-time work: 667,000 (up 68,000)
- Looking for part-time work: 1,002,000 (down 27,000)

**Under-employment:**
- 1,787,000 (11.1% of workforce, up 0.4% from November)
- Increased by 78,000 from November

**Combined unemployment and under-employment:**
- 3,456,000 (21.5% of workforce, up 0.6%)
- Has remained above 3 million for 13 consecutive months

**Employment:**
- Total employed: 14,428,000 (up 89,000 from November)
- Part-time employment: 5,279,000 (up 143,000, a new record high, representing 36.6% of employed)
- Full-time employment: 9,149,000 (down 54,000, representing 63.4% of employed)

**Workforce:**
- Total workforce: 16,097,000 (up 130,000 from November)
- Represents 69.2% of Australians aged 14+

**Year-over-year changes (December 2024 to December 2025):**
- Total employment: up 152,000
- Part-time employment: up 326,000
- Full-time employment: down 174,000
- Unemployment: up 127,000 (up 0.7 percentage points)
- Under-employment: up 111,000 (up 0.5 percentage points)
- Combined unemployment and under-employment: up 238,000 (up 1.2 percentage points)

**Population:**
- Australian population aged 14+: 23,261,000 (up 1,816,000 from December 2022)

## Opinions from Named Source:

**Michele Levine, CEO Roy Morgan:**
- Expressed concern that unemployment and under-employment have been above 3 million for over a year
- Characterized the labor market as "sluggish" with "no net full-time jobs created over the last year"
- Attributed low productivity as "stifling growth and leading to labour market stagnation"
- Cited public spending from Federal and State Governments as "the biggest driver of inflation" that "crowds out private investment and reduces economic productivity"
- Recommended government spending cuts to reduce inflationary pressures and allow the Reserve Bank to cut interest rates
- Noted ABS inflation estimates for November 2025 showed CPI at 3.4%, down from October 2025 high of 3.8%
- Compared Australia unfavorably to the US (Federal Reserve cut rates in September, October, December) and New Zealand (Reserve Bank cut rates nine times since August 2024)

## Important Methodological Note:
- Roy Morgan unemployment estimates are **actual data** while ABS estimates are **seasonally adjusted**
- This means these figures are not directly comparable to the ABS seasonally adjusted unemployment rate that the forecasting question resolves on
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.fxstreet.com/news/australias-unemployment-rate-expected-to-tick-higher-in-december-202601212030">
# Summary of Article: Australia Unemployment Rate December 2025 Data

**Source:** FXStreet  
**Date:** January 21, 2026

## Key Facts and Statistics:

### December 2025 Actual Results (released January 21, 2026):
- **Unemployment Rate:** 4.1% (down from 4.3% in November 2025)
  - Market expectation was 4.4%
- **Employment Change:** +65.2K (vs. -28.7K in November, revised from -21.3K)
  - Market expectation was +30K
- **Participation Rate:** 66.7% (up from 66.6% in November, revised from 66.7%)
- **Full-Time Employment:** +54.8K (vs. -65.3K in November, revised from -56.5K)
- **Part-Time Employment:** +10.4K (vs. +36.6K in November, revised from +35.2K)
- **Hours Worked:** +0.4% (matching the 0.4% rise in employment)

### November 2025 Data (for comparison):
- Unemployment Rate: 4.3%
- Employment Change: -28.7K (revised from -21.3K)
- Full-time positions: -65.3K (revised from -56.5K)
- Part-time positions: +36.6K (revised from +35.2K)

## Named Source Opinions:

**Sean Crick, ABS head of labour statistics:**
- More 15-24 year olds moved into employment, contributing to the rise in overall employment and fall in unemployment rate
- Growth in employment was driven by male employment (rose by 49,000), while female employment recorded a smaller increase of 17,000

## Additional Context:

**RBA Monetary Policy:**
- Reserve Bank of Australia scheduled to meet February 3, 2026
- Official Cash Rate unchanged at 3.6% since August 2025
- Annual inflation slowed to 3.4% in November 2025 from 3.8% in October, still above RBA's 2-3% target

**Market Reaction:**
- AUD/USD trading 0.40% higher at 0.6788 following the employment data release

## Less Reliable/Unnamed Source Opinion:

**Valeria Bednarik, Chief Analyst at FXStreet** (opinion from analyst, not government/official source):
- AUD/USD pair trades near recent peak at levels last seen in October 2024
- Pair may seem overbought in near term
- Slides likely to keep attracting buyers as long as dismal mood persists
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.oxfordeconomics.com/key-themes-2026/">
# Summary of "Economic outlook 2026: Key themes & insights" by Oxford Economics

## Key Facts and Statistics Relevant to Australian Unemployment:

**Australia-Specific Content:**
- **Australia faces a series of tussles for 2026**: The article identifies three competing forces: "inflation versus the RBA, public versus private demand and homeowners versus everyone else."

## General Global/Regional Context:

**Global Economy:**
- Global economy expected to remain resilient in 2026 with "solid but unspectacular world GDP growth"
- Diverging prospects across regions is a key theme

**Asia-Pacific Region:**
- Asia will continue to be "the brightest spot in the global economy in 2026"
- However, growth trajectory will likely be "more uneven than in past cycles"
- Japan expected to return to modest growth driven by consumption as US tariff shock dissipates in H1 2026

**Other Regions:**
- US GDP growth expected to outperform consensus by "some margin" (US exceptionalism)
- Eurozone economy to gain momentum but growth will be "lacklustre" without strong policy boost
- UK GDP growth forecast of 1% (at bottom of consensus)

## Source Reliability:
This is from Oxford Economics, a recognized economic forecasting organization. However, the article is primarily promotional content for their services and provides limited specific detail about Australia beyond the brief mention above.

## Note:
The article does not provide specific unemployment rate forecasts or detailed labor market analysis for Australia. The Australian content is minimal and focuses on broader economic tensions rather than employment metrics.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.indailysa.com.au/news/business/2026/02/02/global-economic-outlook-2026-insights-from-bdos-chief-economist">
# Summary of Article: Global Economic Outlook 2026

**Source:** InDaily (South Australia)  
**Date:** February 2, 2026  
**Author/Source:** Anders Magnusson, BDO Chief Economist

## Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **Global Growth Projections (IMF, January 2026):**
   - Global growth estimated at 3.3% in 2026
   - Projected to slow slightly to 3.2% in 2027
   - These projections are slightly stronger than 2025 estimates

2. **World Bank Group:** Also revised growth forecasts for 2026 and 2027 in January (specific figures not provided in article)

## Expert Opinions (Named Source):

**Anders Magnusson (BDO Chief Economist) assesses:**

- The global economy is "resilient on the surface, but increasingly fragile underneath"
- Risks to growth are generally on the downside
- Growth is increasingly concentrated in narrow sectors (technology), leaving the economy more exposed
- Technology investment is propping up growth, but the sector "has not yet proven its productivity dividend"

**On Australia specifically:**
- Australia is "deeply dependent on global growth and commodity flows"
- Export mix includes iron ore, gas, gold, and coal
- Australia must address the trade-off between productivity and protectionism
- Long-term prosperity depends on "resisting the global drift toward inward looking policy and prioritising competitiveness, skills, and innovation"

## Contextual Information:

- Temporary factors that supported activity in early 2025 (trade frontloading ahead of tariff changes) are now unwinding
- Technology investment is picking up as those temporary factors fade
- China's growth is slowing structurally as it transitions from investment-led to consumption-driven economy
- AI made progress in 2025, but 2026 may be when "organisational structures begin to adapt meaningfully"

**Note:** This article focuses on global and Australian economic outlook broadly. It does not contain specific forecasts or data regarding Australian unemployment rates for February 2026.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://kpmg.com/au/en/insights/economics-geopolitics/economic-outlook-australia.html">
# Summary of KPMG Australian Economic Outlook Article

## Key Statistics and Forecasts:

**GDP Performance:**
- September quarter 2025: GDP rose 0.4%, described as a "notable improvement" from earlier in the year
- Recovery driven by strong private investment, household spending, and public sector demand

**KPMG Macroeconomic Forecasts:**

| Indicator | 2024 (actual) | 2025 (forecast) | 2026 (forecast) | 2027 (forecast) |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| Real GDP (average annual growth) | 1.0% | 1.9% | 2.1% | 2.0% |
| Real GDP (year-ended growth) | 1.3% | 2.0% | 2.0% | 2.0% |
| RBA cash rate | 4.35% | 3.60% | 3.60% | 3.60% |
| Headline CPI | 2.4% | 3.3% | 3.0% | 2.6% |
| Core CPI | 3.3% | 3.2% | 2.8% | 2.6% |
| AUD/USD | 0.65 | 0.67 | 0.66 | 0.66 |

## Other Relevant Information:
- Inflation remains above the RBA's target
- Global economy showed resilience in 2025, supported by AI-related investment and accommodative policy settings
- Australia's economic outlook is influenced by both domestic momentum and evolving international conditions

**Note:** This article does not contain specific unemployment rate forecasts for February 2026 or any other period. The forecasts are attributed to KPMG and appear to be from a Q4 2025 report.
</Summary>

<Asknews_articles>
Query: What will the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate be in Australia, for the following months? (February 2026)
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Nightmare on Martin Place as RBA outlines horror interest rates scenario**
The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) released its quarterly Statement of Monetary Policy on February 3, 2026, outlining a starkly divergent economic outlook. While the economy ended 2025 in strong shape—with GDP growth at 2.3% (up from a forecast of 2.0%), a robust jobs market, and stronger-than-expected household consumption and business investment—the outlook for 2026 and beyond is grim. If market expectations for two or more additional rate hikes materialize, the RBA forecasts a sharp economic downturn: GDP is projected to fall to 1.8% by year-end 2026 and 1.6% by mid-2027, household consumption to drop from 3.1% to 2.1%, and unemployment to rise steadily to 4.6% by mid-2028. Underlying inflation is expected to remain at 3.2% at the end of 2026—above the RBA’s 2–3% target—and only reach the comfort zone by early 2028. The RBA attributes much of the recent inflation surge to non-demand-driven factors like durable goods, food, and holiday travel prices, suggesting rate hikes may have limited impact. The forecasts rely on market-based interest rate expectations, creating a circular logic that undermines reliability. Australia’s high sensitivity to rate changes stems from its reliance on variable-rate mortgages and expensive real estate; unlike the U.S., where 30-year fixed rates dominate, Australian households feel rate changes immediately. Some economists suggest the RBA may implement only one rate hike—'one and done'—as the threat of further hikes could be enough to cool spending and prevent further tightening. The RBA emphasized that 'the good news ends there,' underscoring the precariousness of the current economic trajectory.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 03, 2026 05:52 AM
Source:[Australian Broadcasting Corporation](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2026-02-03/rba-decision-to-raise-interest-rates-horror-scenario-outlined/106300520)

**Australia's central bank raises interest rate to 3.85% after 3 cuts**
Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), raised its benchmark cash rate by 0.25 percentage points to 3.85% on February 3, 2026, marking its first rate hike since November 2023. This follows three consecutive rate cuts in 2025, including reductions in February, May, and August. The decision comes amid rising inflation, which reached 3.8% for the 12 months ending December 2025—up from 3.4% in November—and is now seen as likely to remain above the RBA’s target range of 2% to 3% for some time. The bank cited strong private demand driven by household spending and investment as key inflationary pressures. Treasurer Jim Chalmers described the move as 'difficult news' for mortgage holders and businesses, rejecting claims that government spending is fueling inflation. EY Oceania Chief Economist Cherelle Murphy noted the surprise of the rate hike just six months after the last cut, stating that while the prior cut seemed justified at the time, inflation has since rebounded. She also highlighted a drop in the unemployment rate from 4.3% in November to 4.1% in December, suggesting the economy may be 'running a little bit too hot,' and said another rate hike later in 2026 cannot be ruled out.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 03, 2026 05:34 AM
Source:[WSLS](https://www.wsls.com/business/2026/02/03/australias-central-bank-raises-interest-rate-to-385-after-3-cuts/)

**Blow to borrowers with about-face interest rate hike**
The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) raised the cash rate by 25 basis points to 3.85% in a unanimous decision on February 3, 2026, becoming the first major central bank to reverse course from post-COVID rate cuts and initiate rate hikes. This move followed inflation rising above the RBA’s 2–3% target band, with data showing stronger-than-expected labour force participation, consumer spending, and inflationary pressures in the second half of 2025. The board stated that private demand is growing faster than anticipated, capacity constraints are tighter than previously assessed, and the labour market is slightly tight, justifying the rate increase. The decision marks a significant shift from the RBA’s earlier strategy of maintaining lower rates longer to avoid unemployment spikes. Despite expectations—financial markets assigned a 75% probability to a hike—some economists argued for waiting on further data, citing softening monthly inflation and a strong Australian dollar. Domain’s chief economist Nicola Powell warned the hike would reduce housing market momentum by lowering borrowers’ purchasing power. A $600,000 mortgage holder would face an estimated $90 monthly repayment increase if lenders pass on the full rise. In updated forecasts, core inflation is now projected at 3.2% by end-2026, up from 2.7% in November. RBA Governor Michele Bullock’s post-meeting press conference will be closely watched for signals on future rate moves. Treasurer Jim Chalmers acknowledged the hardship for mortgage holders, emphasizing that inflation pressures stem from private demand, not government spending. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, however, urged government spending cuts, arguing that rising public expenditure fuels inflation, higher interest rates, and future tax pressures.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 03, 2026 05:25 AM
Source:[NEOS KOSMOS](https://neoskosmos.com/en/2026/02/03/news/australia/blow-to-borrowers-with-about-face-interest-rate-hike/)

**RBA Raises Interest Rates for First Time in Three Years Amid Inflation Pressure**
On February 3, 2026, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) announced a 0.25 percentage point interest rate hike, raising the cash rate to 3.85%, marking its first increase since November 2023 and the first monetary policy meeting of the year. The RBA stated that inflation may remain above target for some time and that financial conditions, while previously loosened, are uncertain in their restrictive nature. The central bank emphasized its commitment to price stability and full employment, stating it will take necessary measures to achieve these goals. The decision follows economic overheating and elevated inflation, making Australia the first major central bank to raise rates since Japan. Unemployment has reached a 50-year low. Bond traders have shifted from expecting rate cuts to anticipating hikes over the past two months. PIMCO Australia’s portfolio manager Adam Bowe stated that the current cash rate is already restrictive and will help bring inflation back to the 2%–3% target range over time. Finder data shows that a 500,000 AUD mortgage holder would pay an additional 79 AUD monthly (948 AUD annually), while a 1,000,000 AUD borrower would pay 158 AUD more monthly (1,896 AUD annually). Treasurer Jim Chalmers acknowledged the difficulty this decision brings to households and businesses, noting that the RBA’s statement explicitly attributed inflation to private demand, not government spending. He defended the government against criticism, including the opposition’s sarcastic term 'Jimflation.' Roy Morgan data indicates that a 25-basis-point rate hike would put 41,000 mortgages at risk and affect 1.228 million borrowers. All four major banks had predicted the 0.25% hike, with ANZ, Westpac, and CBA viewing it as a one-time move, while NAB forecasts a second hike in May.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 03, 2026 04:39 AM
Source:[The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/b5/26/2/3/n14689952.htm)

**Australia’s Reserve Bank Raises Rates for First Time in Three Years Amid Inflation Pressure**
On February 3, 2026, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) raised the cash rate by 0.25 percentage points to 3.85%, marking its first interest rate hike since November 2023 and the first of the year. The RBA stated that inflation may remain above target for some time and that financial conditions, while previously loosened, are uncertain in their restrictive impact. The central bank emphasized its commitment to price stability and full employment, asserting it will take necessary measures to achieve these goals. The decision followed economic overheating and rising inflation, with Australia’s unemployment rate near a 50-year low. Bond traders shifted from expecting rate cuts to betting on hikes over the past two months. PIMCO’s Adam Bowe stated that the current cash rate is already restrictive and will gradually reduce demand and bring inflation back to the 2%–3% target range. Finder data shows that a $500,000 mortgage borrower would pay an additional $79 per month ($948 annually), and a $1 million borrower would pay $158 more monthly ($1,896 annually) if banks pass on the increase. Finance Minister Jim Chalmers acknowledged the hardship for mortgage holders, stating the RBA’s statement cited private demand, not government spending, as the inflation driver. He faced criticism from opposition MPs, who mocked the inflation as 'Jimflation.' Roy Morgan data estimates 41,000 mortgages at risk and 1.228 million borrowers under financial pressure from the rate hike. Major banks predicted the 0.25% increase, with ANZ, Westpac, and CBA viewing it as a one-time move, while NAB forecasts a second hike in May.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 03, 2026 04:39 AM
Source:[The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/gb/26/2/3/n14689952.htm)

**Grim forecasts for Aussie inflation and unemployment**
The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has released grim new economic forecasts, predicting higher inflation, faster price growth, and lower real income growth. Despite raising interest rates by 0.25 percentage points, the RBA forecasts core inflation will only reach 2.6% by June 2028—still above its 2.5% target—up from a previous forecast of 2.7% in November, now expected to be 3.2% by the end of 2026. The RBA cited stronger-than-expected economic performance, including robust household consumption, business investment, and housing market activity, as well as a lower unemployment rate of 4.1% (below the prior forecast), indicating less spare capacity in the economy. These factors, combined with temporary influences like goods price volatility and domestic travel, are contributing to elevated inflation. Real wages are projected to fall by 0.9% in the year to June 2025—worsening from the previous forecast of a 0.5% decline—marking the end of eight consecutive quarters of real wage growth. The unemployment rate is expected to rise to 4.6% by June 2028, and GDP growth is forecast to be lower than previously estimated beyond June 2026 due to higher cash rate assumptions. The RBA stated that 'elevated capacity pressures are consistent with the recent pick-up in inflation, though less persistent sector-specific factors are assumed to explain most of the recent inflation surprise.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 03, 2026 03:59 AM
Source:[Perth Now](https://www.perthnow.com.au/news/business/grim-forecasts-for-aussie-inflation-and-unemployment-c-21513949)

**Aussie dollar jumps ahead of RBA call**
The Australian dollar rose to US69.71 cents ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) critical interest rate decision on February 3, 2026, following a strong run that saw it reach a three-year high near US71 cents. Market expectations favored a 25 basis point rate hike to 3.85%, with money markets assigning a 75% probability to such an action. Analysts are divided: some, like AMP’s Shane Oliver and InvestSmart’s Ron Hodge, argue inflation is a temporary 'blip' driven by transitory factors, citing falling electricity prices, a stronger Australian dollar reducing import costs, labor market uncertainty from AI, and the risk of 'policy whiplash' if rates are tightened too quickly. Conversely, economists such as Commonwealth Bank’s Luke Yeaman and CreditorWatch’s Ivan Colhoun emphasize rising trimmed mean inflation (3.3% over 12 months to December 2025), a strengthening economy, and strong employment data (unemployment down to 4.1%) as justification for a hike. EQ Economics’ Warren Hogan warned that delaying action risks a deeper economic downturn. If rates rise, mortgage holders face significant financial strain: an average borrower on a $693,802 loan would pay $1,313 more annually; those with $500,000 debt would pay $79 more monthly; and $1 million borrowers would pay $158 more monthly. Roy Morgan data suggests 41,000 additional mortgages could be 'at risk' under a rate hike, with 1.228 million borrowers feeling the financial pinch.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 03, 2026 02:24 AM
Source:[Herald Sun](https://www.heraldsun.com.au/business/economy/reserve-bank-to-decide-on-rate-rise-amid-fears-of-higher-mortgage-repayments/news-story/45f390ecdf3f5bf665e263bff00508b8)

**Australia's January ANZ Total Job Advertisements Rise 4.4% Month-on-Month, Hit Four-Year High**
According to ANZ-Indeed data, Australia's total job advertisements rose by 4.4% month-on-month in January 2025, marking the highest level since February 2022 and surpassing the revised previous month's figure of a 0.8% decline. ANZ economist Aaron Luk stated that the January increase partially offset the gradual slowdown observed in the second half of 2025, bringing the job advertisement series back to approximately the level seen in August 2025. He noted that seasonal interference may have influenced the January data, as the final week of 2025 could have affected seasonal adjustments. Nevertheless, Luk emphasized that labor demand rebounding at the start of the year is not uncommon, citing historical data showing a 6.2% monthly increase in January 2019 and a 3.9% rise in January 2017. He explained that the January rebound followed Australia's December employment increase of 65,200 people and a drop in the unemployment rate to 4.1%. However, overall in 2025, ANZ still views the labor market as 'mixed,' with the unemployment rate returning to its年初 level and employment and working hours growth remaining relatively weak, with annual growth rates around 1%. The bank does not believe December's data signals a significant tightening of the labor market in the near term.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 02, 2026 05:27 AM
Source:[AAStocks.com](https://www.aastocks.com/share/news/fx/NOW.1500427?ntype=1&lang=chi)

**Australian Manufacturing Upswing Gathers Pace**
Australia's manufacturing sector recorded a third consecutive monthly expansion in January 2026, with the seasonally adjusted S&P Global Australia manufacturing purchasing manager's index rising to 52.3 from 51.6 in December—the fastest growth in five months. This expansion was driven by a solid increase in new orders, including a rise in international business. The data supports broader economic momentum, fueled by strong consumer spending, high employment, rising business investment, and elevated government spending. Jingyi Pan, economics associate director at S&P Global Market Intelligence, noted that manufacturing output growth accelerated to match the long-term trend, while employment and purchasing activity increased at historically high rates. She also stated that the new orders and future output indices indicate continued output growth in the coming months. This economic strength coincides with speculation that the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will raise interest rates, aiming to counter renewed inflationary pressures that threaten to push inflation above its 2% to 3% target, following a rate cut in August 2025.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 01, 2026 10:58 PM
Source:[Morningstar](https://www.morningstar.com/news/dow-jones/20260201789/australian-manufacturing-upswing-gathers-pace)

**Unnecessary interest rate cuts derailed the national housing affordability project**
The article argues that the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) interest rate cuts in 2025 undermined national housing affordability efforts. Despite unemployment remaining below the RBA’s full employment threshold of 4.3–4.5%, the RBA cut rates in February 2025, leading to an 8.6% rise in the national median house price—more than double the income growth. This increase was driven by a $264 monthly reduction in mortgage repayments from rate cuts, which was outweighed by a $363 rise in repayments due to higher house prices. The article notes that net permanent and long-term arrivals reached 476,070, increasing demand. The RBA’s actions, while intended to support inflation and employment, directly boosted house prices, contradicting government efforts under the National Housing Accord to improve affordability. The author criticizes the RBA for undermining affordability despite having no formal mandate to do so, contrasting it with U.S. President Donald Trump’s explicit goal of raising house prices to benefit homeowners. The article also highlights that inflation data showing a 3.8% annual rise was skewed by a 24.4% jump in international travel and accommodation, while the seasonally adjusted monthly increase was only 0.2% (2.4% annualized), suggesting inflation is not out of control. Despite market predictions of two rate hikes in Australia in 2026, the author believes a hike tomorrow may not occur. The RBA’s two mandates—price stability and full employment—ultimately converge on inflation control, but the article asserts that monetary policy’s most direct impact is on house prices, which are central to household wellbeing. The author concludes that the RBA’s rate cuts were unnecessary and counterproductive, effectively derailing the national housing affordability project.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 01, 2026 06:48 PM
Source:[Australian Broadcasting Corporation](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2026-02-02/rba-interest-rate-hikes-housing-affordability-inflation/106292572)

**Australia Jobless Rate Lowest in 7 Months | Forex News 2026.01.22 (en)**
Australia's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell to 4.1% in December 2025, down from 4.3% in November and below the projected 4.4%, marking the lowest level since May 2025. The number of unemployed individuals decreased by 29,800 to 628,600, reaching a seven-month low. Of these, those seeking full-time work dropped by 21,400 to 421,700, and those seeking part-time work declined by 8,400 to 206,800. Employment rose by 65,200, reaching a record high of 14.68 million—surpassing the projected 30,000 increase and recovering from a revised 28,700 decline in November. Full-time employment increased by 54,800 to 10.10 million, while part-time jobs rose by 10,400 to 4.58 million. The labor force participation rate edged up to 66.7% from 66.6% in November, falling short of the estimated 66.8%. The underemployment rate decreased to 5.7% from 6.2% in November. Total monthly hours worked increased by 8 million, reaching 2,001 million hours.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 22, 2026 01:14 AM
Source:[InstaForex](https://www.instaforex.com/forex-news/2874040)

**Australia's November Employment Numbers Drop Unexpectedly, 9-Month High Decline; Unemployment Rate Holds Steady**
Australia's seasonally adjusted employment numbers for November decreased by 23,100 compared to October, marking the largest decline in nine months, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. This result contrasted with market expectations of a 20,000 increase and followed a strong 41,200 increase in October. Full-time employment fell by 56,500, while the year-on-year growth in employment slowed to 1.3%, below the population growth rate of 2%. The unemployment rate remained stable at 4.3%, slightly below the expected 4.4%. The labor force participation rate declined from 66.9% to 66.7%, and average working hours remained unchanged. Oxford Economics' lead economist, Hallie Murphy-Cruze, noted that part of the decline may reflect a temporary rebound after October's strong gain, but emphasized that the underlying trend indicates a gradual slowdown in the labor market. This weakening data may reduce the likelihood of an imminent interest rate hike by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The Australian dollar fell 0.1% to US$0.6667, and the Australian 3-year bond futures rose 9 ticks to 95.85. Swap market pricing reflects a 23% probability of a rate hike in February 2026 and approximately 70% probability in May 2026.
Original language: ja
Publish date: December 11, 2025 02:37 AM
Source:[ニューズウィーク日本版 オフィシャルサイト](https://www.newsweekjapan.jp/headlines/world/2025/12/581286.php)

**What a surprise spike in the unemployment means for interest rates and the economy**
Australia's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose from 4.3% in August to 4.5% in September 2025, the highest level since November 2021 and the tenth consecutive month above 4%. This unexpected increase strengthens the case for the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) to cut the official cash rate in November. The RBA's mandate includes achieving 'the maximum level of employment consistent with low and stable inflation,' but current unemployment is well above any credible estimate of full employment. Employment growth has slowed significantly in 2025, with an average of only 12,900 new jobs per month compared to 33,900 job seekers, while employment growth in 2024 averaged 32,600 per month. The decline in employment is not due to reduced growth in the non-market sector (such as government services, NDIS, and childcare), which continues at previous rates, but rather due to a drop in the market sector, where private employers are cutting back on hiring amid perceived weaker economic conditions. Additional indicators include a decline in monthly hours worked (from 0.27% in 2024 to 0.04% in 2025), a slowdown in job creation (351,600 in 2024 vs. 44,100 in first half of 2025), and a rise in underemployment from 9.9% to 10.4%. According to Professor Jeff Borland of the University of Melbourne, these data points collectively signal a weakening labour market, making a rate cut more likely.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 17, 2025 05:40 AM
Source:[7NEWS.com.au](https://7news.com.au/lifestyle/real-estate/what-a-surprise-spike-in-the-unemployment-means-for-interest-rates-and-the-economy-c-20382752)

**Rising unemployment could trigger earlier rate cuts**
The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Labour Force Survey revealed that the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose from 4.3% to 4.5%, surpassing market expectations of a modest increase to 4.3%. This rise was driven by an increase in the participation rate to 67.0%, despite a net addition of 15,000 jobs—8,700 full-time and 6,300 part-time. The underemployment rate also increased to 5.9%, indicating softening labor market conditions. Matt Bell, Chief Economist at Oliver Hume, stated that the unexpected jump in unemployment will prompt the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) to reconsider its rate cut timeline, potentially bringing November and December cuts back into play. Although the unemployment rate is now at its highest level in nearly four years, it remains historically low, supporting ongoing wage growth and household incomes. Monthly hours worked rose to 1,987 million. August’s employment figures were revised downward from a reported loss of 5,400 jobs to a loss of 11,900, indicating a weaker labor market than initially thought. Bell noted that the property market remains resilient, with strong new land sales activity continuing into the September quarter, and expects this trend to persist through 2025 regardless of the November and December rate decisions. The upcoming September quarter inflation data, due on October 29, 2025, will heavily influence the RBA’s November policy decision.

**What a surprise spike in the unemployment rate means for interest rates and the economy**
Australia's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose from 4.3% in August to 4.5% in September 2025, the highest level since November 2021 and the tenth consecutive month above 4%. This increase strengthens the case for the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) to cut the official cash rate in November. The RBA's mandate includes achieving 'maximum employment consistent with low and stable inflation,' but the current unemployment rate exceeds any credible estimate of full employment. Employment growth has slowed significantly in 2025, averaging only 12,900 new jobs per month compared to 33,900 job seekers, while employment growth in 2024 averaged 32,600 new jobs monthly. The decline in employment is not due to reduced government spending in the non-market sector—such as health care, education, and public administration—where hours worked remain stable. Instead, the drop is driven by a contraction in the market sector, as private employers are reducing hiring in response to weaker economic conditions. Additional indicators include a decline in average monthly hours worked from 0.27% in 2024 to 0.04% in 2025, and a rise in underemployment from 9.9% to 10.4% since late 2024. These trends collectively signal a cooling labour market.

**Breaking: Australia's unemployment rate jumps to 4.5pc**
Australia's unemployment rate increased to 4.5% in September 2025, up from 4.3% in August, according to seasonally adjusted data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. This marks the highest seasonally adjusted unemployment rate since November 2021. The rise was driven by an increase in both men and women seeking work, resulting in a 33,900 increase in the number of unemployed individuals. Meanwhile, employment rose by 14,900, and the labor force participation rate increased by 0.1 percentage points to 67%. In trend terms, which smooths out seasonal fluctuations, the unemployment rate remained unchanged at 4.3%.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 16, 2025 01:01 AM
Source:[Australian Broadcasting Corporation](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-10-16/australia-unemployment-rate-rises-september-2025/105898244)

**Unemployment surge opens door for rate cuts**
Australia’s unemployment rate rose to 4.5% in September 2025, up 0.2 percentage points from August’s revised 4.3%, marking the highest seasonally adjusted rate since November 2021, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). This increase, driven by 34,000 more unemployed individuals, pushed the underemployment rate up by 0.2 percentage points to 5.9%, raising the underutilisation rate to 10.4%—a 0.4 percentage point rise. Despite the weak headline, employment grew by 14,900 (with 60% full-time and 40% part-time), and aggregate monthly hours worked increased by 0.5%. The trend unemployment rate rose to 4.32%, slightly above the Reserve Bank of Australia’s (RBA) forecast peak of 4.3%. The RBA had previously projected unemployment would peak at 4.3% and remain there until late 2027. The surge in unemployment increases pressure on the RBA to consider earlier and deeper interest rate cuts, despite ongoing inflation concerns. The upcoming Q3 CPI inflation data, due on 29 October 2025, will be critical in determining whether a rate cut occurs in November.

**Australia Jobless Rate Holds Steady at 4.2% | Forex News 2025.09.18...**
Australia’s seasonally adjusted unemployment rate held steady at 4.2 % in August 2025, matching the previous month’s figure and market expectations. The number of unemployed people fell by 900 to 647,400. Part‑time job seekers dropped 3,600 to 204,400, while full‑time seekers rose 3,000 to 443,000. Employment declined by 5,400 to 14.63 million, missing the anticipated 22,000 increase after July’s revised rise of 26,500 and marking the first month‑to‑month downturn in three months. Full‑time employment fell 40,900 to 10.08 million; part‑time employment rose 35,500 to 4.55 million. The labour‑force participation rate slipped to 66.8 % from 67 %, the lowest since March. The underemployment rate fell slightly from 5.8 % to 5.7 %. Total hours worked across all jobs decreased 8 million to 1,977 million.
